New Delhi

New Delhi, Feb. 9 -- The Supreme Court on Tuesday called the protracted legal battle between Amazon and Future Group "a luxury litigation", expressing displeasure at unending requests being made by one party or another. "Where is this going to end? This is nothing but a luxury litigation, we must say now," remarked a bench, headed by Chief Justice of India (CJI) NV Ramana.

The bench, which also comprised justices AS Bopanna and Hima Kohli, was livid after Amazon sought to file a seven-page note regarding a matter in which the court had reserved its judgment on February 3.

Senior advocate Nakul Dewan mentioned the case before the bench on behalf of Amazon for permission to file written submissions. "These are written submissions of senior advocate Gopal Subramanium. May we please place them on record for the assistance of this court?" Dewan submitted. He also informed the bench that the submissions are a seven-page note. But the bench was miffed. "What's this? We reserved the judgment last week and now you want to submit written submissions. What if we had already prepared our judgment? If you want to delay the matter, we don't have any problem," it responded.

At this, senior advocate KV Vishwanathan, appearing for Future Group, opposing Amazon's plea on the ground that it appeared an attempt to delay the proceedings.

"What else are we saying? We don't agree with such a practice. We are in the process of getting our judgment ready and someone wants to file a seven-page note. It is better not to hear these luxury litigations," retorted the CJI.

Justice Ramana then consulted with the fellow judges on the bench and declined to take Subramanium's note on record.

On February 3, the court reserved judgment on certain aspects of the dispute between Amazon and Future over the latter's proposed $3.4 billion sale of retail assets to Reliance.

The bench, on that occasion, heard Amazon's arguments asserting that Future cannot be permitted to go ahead before the National Company Law Tribunal (NCLT) for shareholders' approval for its proposed deal with Reliance in the wake of a restraining order by an international arbitration tribunal.

Future's proposed $3.4 billion sale of retail assets to Reliance has been left in a lurch after Amazon initiated arbitration proceedings, citing its 2019 deal with Future.
